Award.AwardTitle: Development of Generalized-Ensemble Algorithms and their Application in Protein Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ulrich Hansmann of Michigan Technological University is supported by an award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program for work to further develop generalized-ensemble algorithms for use in protein folding simulations. Partial funding for this award has been provided by the Molecular Biophysics program within the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.

After the successful deciphering of whole genomes a new challenge has emerged: for most of the newly found sequences we do not know the function of the corresponding proteins. Reliable computational tools that allow one to study the emergence of structure and function of proteins from their sequence of amino acids would therefore lead to deeper insight in the molecular foundation of the fundamental processes in cells. Exploring this relationship in computer simulations is extremely difficult for detailed protein models, and the computational effort to calculate accurately physical quantities increases exponentially with the number of residues in simple room-temperature simulations. In order to overcome this difficulty, the PI has pioneered the generalized ensemble approach and demonstrated its feasibility for simulation of peptides and proteins of up to 40-50 amino acids. By further advancing this approach and implementing it in his highly scalable software package SMMP the PI aims at deriving models that will describe folding and interaction of stable domains in proteins (usually consisting of 50-200 amino acids). Connecting optimization of algorithms to fundamental ideas of statistical mechanics the PI is probing folding and assembly of the 75-residue apo calbindin D9K and the 84-residue tetramer BBTA2; and binding of copper ions to the 37-residue truncated form of yeast copper thionein. His goal is to understand these processes solely from the physical interactions between the atoms within a protein, and between the protein and the surrounding environment. The work is, thus, having a broad impact on the field of biology as well as through the involvement of students, including some American Indian students, in this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A detailed knowledge of protein structure and function is of critical importance in many medical and biotechnological applications. Despite decades of research, the relationship between amino acid sequence and structure/function of proteins is still only poorly grasped. Hence, there is a need for reliable computational tools that complement experiments in studying folding and interaction of proteins, leading to new insight into the molecular machinery of cells. This research project has developed techniques for simulation of proteins in a detailed, atomistic description, and applied these techniques to carefully chosen proteins.

As a rule, the computational effort to calculate accurately physical quantities in simulations increases exponentially with the size of a protein. Our laboratory has pioneered the generalized-ensemble approach and replica-exchange techniques as a way to alleviate these numerical difficulties. We have analyzed systematically the efficiency of these techniques and have devised strategies that optimize their use, especially for the case of protein simulations with explicit solvent. The problem here is the need for small temperature spacing (and therefore large number of replicas) to avoid poor acceptance rates for replica exchanges. As one possible approach, my graduate student Parimal Kar developed rejection-free moves and and tested them for small proteins. Interestingly, we found that such moves by themselves do not guarantee higher sampling efficiency.  We showed that this problem can be avoided by combining regular and rejection-free moves. Over the last year we took a fresh look at the velocity scaling approach, no longer using it to obtain rejection-free replica-exchange moves, but rather to compensate for the effects of solvent that make replica exchange simulations with explicit solvent so costly.

While considerable progress could be made optimizing replica exchange and other generalized-ensemble simulations are still computationally costly, and protein simulations still require large computer systems. In the past, we have developed in collaboration with groups in Germany and Taiwan the program package SMMP, a free software for simula- tion of proteins in an all-atom description. The latest release contains an implementation of SMMP in Python and allows simulation of interacting proteins. Considerable effort was put on the parallelization of SMMP that scales now almost linearly for up to 8192 processors on a BlueGene/L.

Connecting optimization of algorithms to fundamental ideas of statistical mechanics our laboratory has study the folding and aggregation of selected proteins. These proteins were chosen either because they allowed us to probe fundamental questions or are of medical importance. For instance, with the C-fragment of TOP7 we studied a potential mechanism by that proteins with end-to-end beta sheet may avoid misfolding and aggregation.
